reviewText: A classic point-n-click, reminding me on the good times when this genre was much more appreciated.\nNice story, cool intro and outro movies, well balanced puzzles: not too hard and not too lame, you can solve everything by using your brain, but you won't need to go into annoying pixel-hunting.\nA really great work from such a small group of game makers. Keep on bringing more titles like this!

reviewText:
So I played this waaaaay back as a free flash game and it was amazing when it first came out. Really big game for the time and fabulous graphics with actually interesting cinematics.

If you try and find it online today, it's sad that the voice work has been removed. When I saw it on here, I kinda rejoiced. It's not terribly long, or complicated, but somehow everything just fits right. It's a nice, honest, and surprisingly solid little adventure game. Thankfully, the game's been remastered a bit. The graphics aren't much better, but they are slightly improved. Some new voice work. It's about as quality as its previous iteration but I actually like it a lot. It somehow strikes me as fitting in spite of it being rather deadpan. I miss the character portraits though.

Anyhoo, the game doesn;t have too much additional content compared to its free counterpart, so it's up to you whether you want this experience, or the slightly less in-depth one. The differences aren't worth the price tag, but if you've got the cash, I'd recommend the buy. The game's solid and I'd love to see the developers get some support and make a new game. They definitely got some talent for it.

All in all, I'm quite happy with my purchase and would suggest it, though for obvious reasons it's not for everbody.

reviewText: Short but very enjoyable. It is pretty good at $10 would be a must have if ever on sale. The characters are remarkable reserved for their plight and have a dark humour. I found no bugs during my gameplay and the puzzles are inuitive and follow common sense. It hint at a bigger stoyline and would definitely deserve a sequal, if not episodic, release.

reviewText:
Morningstar: Descent to Deadrock is a short compelling little point-and-click adventure from space following in the big steps of games aka The Dig.
Gameplay wise it's a solid piece of work. You combine various objects which each other and find new and unconventional solutions to otherwise unsolvable problems
Musically it's nice outerspace ambient sound..kinda. Very relaxed and subtle 7.5 of 10 because the could have dared more with the sounds and music.
I don't want to spoil to much, but seasoned adventure gamers won't be surprised by the story. But the first-person view adds some new element and the solutions are sometimes quite unexpected.
Overall I would recommend it to all of you adventure gamers looking for something new for a decent price.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P4j-aCRtXOY

A man named Powell awakens from the hibernation chamber and learns that one of his crew mates didn't survive. He heads to the cockpit to find the Captain of the ship impaled through the stomach by a random piece of debris. He takes a seat and reins in the damaged vehicle as it cascades to the planet below. Powell must now explore the planet and find a way to repair his broken ship.

High Points

Engineering puzzles – The puzzles are sound from an engineering perspective. You’ll find materials and parts to fix broken equipment and structures around the planet. Powell and the Captain will give us hints on how to use the parts, and from those hints we will craft makeshift sensors and explosives.

Creepy Atmosphere – Descent to Deadrock has a truly creepy feel to it. Stone statues of unknown origin watch over a sandy wasteland. Wrecked ships and dead bodies are strewn about the desolate planet leaving only the mystery of how they died. It creates a tense sensation while you search for a means to escape.

Average Points

Dem Graphics – The visuals are very 1998, and that would be acceptable if not for the stillness of the game play. It reminds me of older games like Shadowgate or Déjà Vu. You are mostly watching a still image that only reacts when you interact with a puzzle piece. I wouldn't say it’s bad, but it could use a touch of life to the environments. Wind blowing the sand, the Captain struggling to breathe in his suit, anything that makes the world feel alive.

Low Points

Voice Acting – The voice acting for the main character isn't awful, but it’s not very effectual or interesting. It’s clear that this person is just reading his lines off a sheet of paper, and not trying to inject emotion to the situation at hand. The Captain of the ship provides hints and information and he’s actually worse than the main character. I found it difficult to care about the situation when the characters themselves don’t seem to give a damn.

Clickity Click – Morningstar is an adventure game that’s a bit too far in the past. You will swirl around the cursor on the screen looking for places to interact with. The game gives you some reasonable tells to solve most puzzles and even a nice hint system. However, there are still places where you’ll have to just randomly click on items to solve a puzzle.

Short game – You can beat this game in 3 to 4 hours even after all the random clicking. You can just plow right on through to the ending sequence without much of a problem. The ending is anti-climactic as well, and it never really solves a few of the mysteries on the planet.

Conclusion

Morningstar: Descent to Deadrock hearkens back to the olden days of adventure gaming. It is light on animation and the voice acting is only tolerable. I recommend that only fans of the adventure genre invest in the short but eventful game play. If you’re not a fan of the adventure genre it isn't going to convince you to join the genre, and the bad voice work and older design might just scare you off.

reviewText:
Rose Tinted

I've always had a soft spot for Point and Click adventure games, they take me back to an earlier time in my gaming career when I could sit down in front of the latest Lucasarts game and lose myself with Loom, Full Throttle or Monkey Island.

My rose tinted view of these old classics tends to forget the ridiculously convoluted inventory puzzles that made up a large part of the problem solving mechanic in these games.


Random Combinations

You remember those frustrating puzzles where you'd find yourself spending hours combining items  in your inventory at random to try and figure out what on earth you're supposed to do next.

This isn't a problem you're likely to encounter in Morningstar, A point and click sci-fi adventure developed by Red Herring Labs.


It's Logical Captain

The puzzles here are entertaining and logical,  if you put a little thought into each problem you encounter here (which are mostly about finding parts and fixing machinery) then you're unlikely to find yourself stuck for too long without having to resort to the I don't know why I'm trying to combine these items" tactic that was required in the old school titles.


Scanning for Pixels

There aren't  really any hidden object puzzles to  worry about  either
date: everything item you'll need should be fairly apparent to you as you move your mouse around the screen. There are no frustrating pixel hunts to stress you out.\n\nThis simplistic approach is  quite refreshing and  allows you to focus on the titles main selling point
recommended:
the story.


A Tale With Impact

Descent to Deadrock tells a compelling and mysterious tale.

The game opens with your ship crashing onto a seemingly barren desert planet. There are only two survivors
voteText: like the ship itself
helpfulPercent: is in a bad  way following the crash
votesHelpful:
so it's  going to be down to you to find the items you'll need to try and repair the ship and hopefully escape the planet.

Along the way you'll scratch the surface of some of the mysteries Deadrock keeps.
Don't expect full disclosure though
votesTotal: Deadrock holds its secrets tightly and your main goal here is to escape the planet
votesFunny:
there will be unanswered questions after you complete this game.


Finish Him

And complete it you will...
It's the strong intriguing story that'll keep  you playing though the couple of hours required to complete Morning Star.
You'll probably finish it in one sitting
commentsCount: which isn't necessarily a  bad thing.\nThere's a lot to be said for a bite sized
column16: focused tale that completes its story arc in two hours.\nA movie gives us a couple of hours entertainment and that is exactly what you'll get here
column17:
two hours of sci-fi mystery interspersed with some exploration and problem solving.


Static Atmosphere

Based on an old flash game
column18: this outing of Morningstar presents itself mostly as static screens where you'll be searching for and using items to either fix machinery or get past obstacles.\nThese static visuals are nothing if not atmospheric
column19: the stillness in each location creates a sense of tension and isolation as you explore your crashed ship and later the surrounding area of Deadrock.\nDue to all this stillness
column21: it has a much greater impact than you'd imagine.\n\nThere are also some cut scenes
column23: but they are very effective in pulling you into the moment
column24:
I just wish there were more of them.


Did you hear that...

The game is fully voiced
column25: and whilst the voice acting isn't going to win any awards
column26:
it is competent enough to keep the story moving forward without breaking the immersion.


Going Down?

Should you get Morningstar: Descent to Deadrock?

That depends on what you're looking for in a point and click adventure game.

If you're looking for an epic
column27: sweeping tale to lose yourself in for weeks
column28: challenging puzzles and state of the art cut scenes
column31: if you're looking to invest a couple of hours in an enigmatic sci-fi setting
column32: enjoy some thoughtful but not too challenging puzzles and be entertained in an encapsulated narrative experience
column33: then you could do a lot worse than spend an evening with Morningstar.\n\n( To view the full review (and others) please take the time to visit http://www.review-well.com/  )"

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5WrsDVbXfJM

Morningstar; Descent to Dearock is a sci-fi point and click adventure where you play as the survivor of a ship that has crashed onto a planet.  While there is no time limit to the game, the atmosphere conveys a need to progress through in order to escape as soon as possible.  The voice acting is pretty bad, making it hard to push through, but as you play through the game, there is less dialogue making it easier to stomach the farther you get in the game.

The story is decent, and does a good job of connecting you to the character that you pay as, but it is the gameplay that makes this game worth playing. You need to find items as you progress through the world and combine these items in different ways in order to progress forward. It doesn't feel like a scavenger hunt, as so many adventure games do.  The game didn't hold my hand as I went through, but it did use  puzzles and items in such a way that I had to use my brain, and work to solve the problems (even through the hint system is tied well into the story and doesn't make you feel like a cheater). This made me feel more like the character that was portrayed rather than some 3rd party player, thus why it may of added to the difficulty at times, but this also help set a stronger atmosphere.

The game was solid and sensible, and I enjoyed playing this game despite its few flaws.

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watch
if you are looking for a more in-depth review.

Thanks for your viewership and support; for more videos click here:

http:/www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

reviewText: This is actually a great point and click adventure game. I played it through in one sitting due to it's engrossing storyline and not known what would happen next. It is extremely atmospheric with eerie sounds and the locations are well drawn which gives you the overall feeling of being alone on a strange planet. The voice acting is very good too and suits the game well. Puzzles were a little convoluted at times but enjoyable enough and satisfying when you finally crack them. All in all,  I really enjoyed it and is well worth a few hours of anyone's time who enjoy this genre of games.

reviewText:
I enjoyed it, but its *really* short. I don't rush through games and didn't use a walkthrough, but Steam tells me that I took 2 hours to complete the game . Give that includes 45 minutes on a pixel hunting puzzle near the end of the game, I don't recommend it for people concerned about price per hour.

Pros:
Graphics are good for an indie point & click
No mazes, sliding block,  or music puzzels
Dialog can be advanced if you read faster than the actors speak
Well paced
Cons:
Launch price is very high for such a short game. Wait for a sale.
There is one puzzle near the end of the game that's basically a pixel hunt on a screen well away from the screen that the puzzle itself is on. Hopefully the devs will either patch the hint system to help here, or make the object more noticable.
If you only enjoy Monkey Island / Sherlock Holmes level of difficulty, you'll not enjoy this game.

reviewText: For the seasoned fan of point-and-click graphical adventures, this game could provide a reasonable morsel to tide you over between other releases. It was entertaining enough to play for the time it lasted, but it's short (about two hours), the voice acting is abysmal, and the story is not particularly gripping or compelling. The great mysteries of the planet never really get plumbed, many of the puzzles have solutions that strain plausibility, there's an awful lot of pixel hunting (the only part I finally looked up in a walkthrough turned out to hinge just on me having not seen a hot spot on the screen -- once I was alerted to that, it was fine), and not LOTS of try-this-with-that, but not none either. All of these design issues will be familiar to, and probably reasonably okay with the seasoned fan as mentioned above, but likely frustrating to anyone who isn't used to dealing with such things regularly. I did enjoy playing it for the evening it took, but I suspect within a couple of months I won't remember that it existed.

reviewText:
A nice, simple point-and-click adventure game. Clean design, puzzles that are interesting, but aren't overly complex, and a nice general aesthetic all make the game quite enjoyable. The only downsides are that it's a rather short game, and the voice acting is a bit deadpan (although not to the point of distraction).

Overall, it might be a bit too short to justify a full prices buy, but it's definitely worth a look whenever it's on sale.

reviewText:
Pleasing, simple, if short point & click game. Figure about 2 hours to complet + all achievements.

Very nice artwork and a cool, not too over-dramatized atmosphere. Although you run across dead crew here and there, the game wasn't too gory and annoying, except maybe the captain's initial condition.

The voice work ranges from very good to quite poor, usually it's quite good but it boggles me when a voice actor doesn't know which word receives emphasis in a phrase... I can only imagine it's a general lack of reading proclivity. It happens in many games with voiceovers and this one more than usual. Still, most of the time it's fine.

The puzzles are generally easy but fairly satisfying. It's mostly linear but you do get to roam a few locations sometimes to look around and try things.

The rapport between the captain and protag is mostly good but a little cheesy at times. And a bit of animation on the captain woul have helped, it felt like you were talking to a painting at times.

Anyway I enjoyed it and finished it in 2 sittings. There was only one poor puzzle part I got stuck on, the ventilator near the generator.
But I can recommend this as a nice, short point & clicker.

reviewText:
Very short, but interesting enough point and click adventure.
I finished it in 2.1(!) hours, admittedly I did consult a walkthrough, but only towards the end, when the puzzles got slightly abstract. That being said however, I expect that a more experienced point and click player would finish this game even without a walkthrough in less than 3 hours.

I got the game cheap and was well immersed in it, so I won't complain too much about the short game lenght.
Think of it as a movie, but instead of being a passive viewer you control the events (albeit linear) yourself.
To back that up, it even has a cheesy action ending :P

reviewText:
I can honestly say I was thinking about playing the original Morningstar game, when the title of the tituar game came accross my screen.

Sure enough, Morningstar: Descent To Deadrock is a complete HD remake of the original 2009 flash game, but fear not, it's not the same game with prettier graphics, oh no, Morningstar-DTD has added over 30 minutes of new gameplay, complete with a new and exciting ending.

Sure enough, you play as 'Powell' a crew-member of the Morningstar space-ship, which hits (literrally) a bit of a problem in the shape of crash-landing on a forbidden and mysterious planet (also nicknamed 'Deadrock).

As the only guy who's either alive or not impaled, it's up to Powell's job to fix the ship and explore this seemingly dead planet......which may not be so dead afterall!

I'm not sure whether the game's creators employed the same voice-artists from the original game, but they've done a fairly satisfying job.

The graphics are nice and so is the interface, though admittedly i did have to consult the walkthrough on a few occassions....but most of the time, the slightly impaled Captain Novak can offer words of assistance and encouragement via the radio.

Overall, Morningstar-DTD is a fine remake and makes me long for a sequel or at least more explaination about the mysterious the 'Deadrock' holds, but for almost 3 hours of gameplay for a small price, I was quite delighted.

So.......sequel please.......pretty please, with beer on top?!

reviewText:
I'm just gonna give this a thumbs up review because it deserves it. For all those short narrative focused games on steam  that just bore your pants off, this one nails it. Sure it's a point and click with puzzles, but they aren't crazy or outlandish like in most of the great classics, so even if you're not any good at solving puzzles in point n clicks this one should be doable. All puzzles can be solved by using plane logic (unlike so many other point and clicks), so they are easy enough. I was delighted being able to get through it without needing a guide - something I consider a good thing.
It's fast paced and therefore doesn't get boring. You progress fast and get to see new things. The downside of this is that it's pretty short. It took me 2 and a half hours to complete. However I didn't get stuck much, so you might get some more time out of it.
I'd recommend getting it on sale (like I did :) ) then you most likely won't regret buying it if you enjoy a nice little Sci-Fi Short Story.
On a last note: Some review mentioned bad voice acting. Initially I would have agreed regarding the captain. But as soon as I put 1+1 together the bad" voice acting actually added some charm to the character

reviewText:
I'm just gonna give this a thumbs up review because it deserves it. For all those short narrative focused games on steam  that just bore your pants off, this one nails it. Sure it's a point and click with puzzles, but they aren't crazy or outlandish like in most of the great classics, so even if you're not any good at solving puzzles in point n clicks this one should be doable. All puzzles can be solved by using plane logic (unlike so many other point and clicks), so they are easy enough. I was delighted being able to get through it without needing a guide - something I consider a good thing.
It's fast paced and therefore doesn't get boring. You progress fast and get to see new things. The downside of this is that it's pretty short. It took me 2 and a half hours to complete. However I didn't get stuck much, so you might get some more time out of it.
I'd recommend getting it on sale (like I did :) ) then you most likely won't regret buying it if you enjoy a nice little Sci-Fi Short Story.

reviewText:
I wasn't sure what to expect going into Morningstar: Descent to Deadrock, but I will say, I was very pleasantly surprised by this title.

I'm a fan of the Point & Click genre in general.  If you've played a few games in the genre, you know what to expect; you'll wander around, collect some items, try to combine them in logical ways, and when that doesn't work, try to combine them with anything interactable.  You might encounter some logical leaps, or other mini-puzzles along the way.  If that's not for you, stay away from this title.

There's lots of this type of game available on Steam, though, so how does this one in particular stack up?

In my opinion?  Very well!

First, the atmosphere is spot on.  A sand-covered world filled with scraps of twisted metal, weird alien structures, and the corpses of the unfortunate, Deadrock gives just the right amount of sci-fi macabre I'd expect from the title.  Add in a handful of really great-looking cinematics, and you've got yourself a nice little experience.

Another major plus is the banter between your hero, and Novak, an injured smart-alec captain who serves as your point-of-contact during your exploration.  Major props to his voice actor, who got a lot more chuckles out of me than I'd expect from a game like this.

The adventure is a short one, and falls a bit on the easy side.  However, one of the reasons the game feels easy is because all of the puzzles feel like they make perfect sense, which is SO refreshing.

There's no BS acheivement hunting in this game; what you see is what you get, and completing the title will earn you 100%.  And that 100% will be all the sweeter because the ending of this game is without a doubt extremely satisfying.  This is definitely worth a playthrough.

Sole minus: The voice actors could have put a bit more enthusiasm into their sentences.\nOverall a good rainy-day" game."

reviewText:
I don't like pre-rendered graphics with a single point of view for each scene. Makes me feel trapped.
I don't like disappearing intrest markers in point-and-click games. It has me sweeping the screen looking for points when I'm stuck, and that's just frustrating.
I don't like dodgy voice acting. It makes the whole game feel fake and ruins immersion.
I don't like short games, as they tend to leave me wanting more.

So, why am I recommending short a 2D pre-rendered point-and-click game with disappearing intrest markers and dodgy voice acting?

Because it's worth it. The puzzles are logical, the graphics are good, the animations servicable and the atmosphere great.
The fact that it's short is a good thing, actually. It makes it so the voice acting never gets on my nerves, and the game doesn't outstay it's welcome.

At the end, I was satisfied. I'd love to explore more, but then I'd need a free-moving camera, and voice actors that aren't simply reading. I need actors to act.

Maybe not the 9,99€ asking price, but as part of a bundle it was certainly worth my time.

However, this independent title is one that may very well sneak under many a fan of the genre's radar. It was developed by the relatively new studio Red Herring Labs (Nocran Space), which was then picked up for distribution through Phoenix Online Studios. The game itself is touted as being in the category of Atmospheric First Person"
date: placing you in a nightmarish struggle to escape an alien planet in one piece. It also happens to be a remastered version of the older PC title MorningStar. But does this updated entry stand as a good modern take on the style
recommended: or is it nothing more than recycled cliche's that are far from enjoyable?\n\nThis story follows one of the ship's crew mates named Powell. He and the captain are the only survivors of a simple mission

This is a major issue later on (one that made me spend an hour running between three different rooms cursing up a storm as to why the planetary sequences wouldn't do anything to the main device in the ship)

reviewText:
Pro:
Solid voice acting, which seems to be rare for the genre.
Overall the puzzles are decent.
Good graphics for an indie game.
Excellent 'hints' button.
Nice to see a casual point & click game in a (well-done) sci-fi setting. Con:
Some clickable areas are hard to spot, i had to use a walkthrough 2-3 times.
Limited map travel and just a tad too much backtracking.
Inventory gets a bit cluttered.
I wanted to combine two items but another item had to be added first for no reason, making me think i was doing the wrong thing.
It's a bit short (90 minutes) for a €10 game.Conclusion

Fans of casual adventures/puzzles and hidden object games should give Descent to Deadrock a try, it's an excellent offering by a small developer.

reviewText:
i usually don't go for point & click games because it bores the hell out of me to hover my mouse over every pixel on every screen if i don't want to miss important stuff and be stuck forever because of that.

but i did go for this one because
a) i liked the space theme and
b) i got it for free!

and in fact i quite enjoyed playing this game but it's really kind of short. like i said i'm not into that point & click stuff but even i managed to finish this game in 2 1/2 hours without overusing the help button.
it's no masterpiece but it was entertaining. and even with a nice and unexpected twist i want to add.

regular point & click players may call this one casual but i really liked the straightforward type of gameplay.
if you run into a problem you usually already have a pretty good idea about how to solve it.
you don't need to scan the screen for tiny and barely visible items or switches and you don't need to combine ten items in the most unthinkable way to get the job done.

tl;dr: decent but short.

reviewText:
This was just ok. I purchased this in the hopes of finding a spacey adventure game with an intense atmosphere like that of The Dig (both involve mostly solitary exploration of strange, desolate alien environments), but was left distinctly underwhelmed by the game in general. It's diverting enough, with enough mileage to absorb somewhat for a few hours, but the plot and characters are basic and lacklustre. There's also no real climax/resolution to the game - while there's a confrontation, it's expected and occurs as a cut scene that is over quite quickly, so there's no real sense of being in real danger at any point or discovery of anything really shocking. The voice acting is rather poor, with some lines read as though the actor doesn't fully understand their context.

On the plus side, the environments are nice to look at (although largely static - the only other character in the game doesn't move) and the puzzles are generally logical and don't require very large leaps of logic, although they're not particularly sophisticated or imaginative, either.

Overall, an easygoing, but ultimately forgettable, few hours.

reviewText: Let me premise my review by saying that this game is not terrible but  it really is not  anywhere near the caliber of a good adventure game. It is a  redux of a mediocre game that added a few new whistles from it's original release years ago . The graphics are average as is the voice acting. The puzzles are not really puzzles but are inventory based. It is also very short and in my opinion well overpriced for what it is.  No camera movement add's to the staleness of it all. I would give it no more than a 5 on a scale to 10, and that is being very generous.

reviewText:
Morningstar is a first person adventure game that feels a lot like Journeyman Project, minus time travel and dialogue. You're crash landed on a desolate planet and need to figure out how to get back to space. You go from screen to screen like good ol' Myst, find items, logs and solve problems. It's a tad short, but it has a good flow to it when it comes to puzzles and level progression.

The prerendered backgrounds and animations are great, and everything is in high quality detail. The music and sound effects are also pretty sweet, but the voice acting is cringeworthy. The writing itself is okay, though. The setting is developed just enough to keep you going, but no questions are answered.

Apparently, there is a free Flash version of the game present on sites like Kongregate and Newgrounds, so you can try it there first. 9 Euros/Dollars for this might be a bit overpriced. If it was around 6 I feel like it would be more appropriate. (I can't complain, really, since I got it in a bundle.)

TL;DR
+ nice puzzles
+ decent setting
+ detailed art and sound
- bad voiceacting
- short

If you like adventures, give it a shot!

reviewText:
Gameplay
Morningstar is pretty standard first-person point & click adventure. Think Myst but with simpler puzzles and lots of combining inventory items. Most of the time the puzzles take the right amount of thought to sort out, though it took me forever to figure one out. Another pre-supposed that you had an idea what went in to gunpowder, which I luckily did. There isn't really a way to fail or die though, so trial and error is safe and will get you through the game. Sometimes his hints seem to be so general as to not help you at all, however.

Story
The story is written well enough to hold my interest for the 1.7 hours it took to beat, but the voice acting is somewhat amateurish. The main character is fine, but the only other voiced character, Novak, has an accent that swings from Swedish to Russian to Spanish, which can be irritating.

Overall
This is an ejoyable game with good story and somewhat dated graphics.

If you're looking to buy it I'd wait for a sale; $10 seems a little steep for 1.7 hours of gameplay that you most likely won't repeat. I even got all the acheivements on the first playthrough. Maybe look for it to show up in a bundle, too. I think I got it from an IndieGala bundle.

reviewText: I really enjoyed the sci-fi atmosphere and setting of this game. It kept me entertained while was playing it. I wish there were more quality less strategy intensive sci-fi games like this on the market.

reviewText:
This game definltey leans back to the days of the old point-and-click games, and that's a good thing. You can get a few hours out of this game, and none of it is particularly difficult. Showing a lot of love from the old-school point-and-click days, all of the backgrounds appear to be hand-painted, which only adds charm as far as I'm concerned. The inventory system is easy to use and you'll need to drag some items onto another item to create a new item. Not all of these combinations are obvious, so you might end up trying a few things; but none of it leads to frustration.

The story itself isn't bad, but it feels like a lot of disjointed ideas that are thrown together. For example, one area shows an alien that's been stabbed to death in a hidden room and supposedly the body is still warm, meaning that it's a very recent murder. Nothing of this situation is ever resolved. The alien is never identified, the murderer is never revealed, the reason for the murder is never established, and there is nothing to link it with the rest of the story anyway. So, why bother introducing them in the first place? Also, human technology just so happens to be compatible with alien technology. That's quite a coincidence.

What made this game difficult to get through was the voice acting. Oh, dear God! It's by no means the worst I've ever heard, but that's not saying much. It's bad! Reading lines while utterly bored" might be more appropriate.

Still
hoursPlayed: and the throwback to the days of classic point-and-click gaming made this worth playing. You might want to turn the speech off
voteText: though."

reviewText: I had the pleasure of playing this game in 2009 when it was merely a flash game on Kongregate. It was a phenomenal game with a compelling story. It sucked you into the universe right away. It was was my favourite point and click game. I am very happy to say that this remastered version is everything I hoped it would be. The graphics are way better and are updated perfectly, but it still keeps the feel of the old flash game. The cutscenes are really cinematic unlike the original. They have also additionally added around an extra 20 minutes of gameplay with an extra objective with new puzzles. There is also decent voice acting that is included. In the original there was just a ton of reading. Overall this is still the best point and click game I've ever played and I highly recommend to fans of the genre. I am going to give Morningstar: Descent to Deadrock a 9.5/10 It only didnt get a perfect rating because its main story is a little short. Please buy this game and show support to the developers and hopefull we can get a sequel to this amazing game!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I do enjoy a good point and click adventure game, but sometimes they get a little complicated and drag on. Morningstar's strength and weakness is its length. It sticks around long enough for you to not to get bored of it, but not long enough to answer any real questions about the story itself. I found this a little disheartening, because I found the story itself quite interesting throughout most of the game.

The difficulty felt pretty balanced overall, but definitely had some hitches. I found myself lost on only two puzzles, one due to pixel hunting and another due to the game not explaining too well what items I was actually holding in my inventory. There is a 'Radio' option to help guide you towards your next goal, but is useless in providing hints.

Overall:  A good distraction for an afternoon, but not much else.

Amount to Pay:  About $2. I paid that for a bundle in which this was the only game I didn't have, and I don't regret it.

reviewText:
A good callback to classic point-and-click adventures.
What it lacks in depth, it tries to make up for in earnest gameplay.
While not complicated or difficult, Morningstar: Descent to Deadrock is a good way to spend two hours solving puzzles and exploring limited lore.
With good graphics and an interesting premise and setting, Morningstar is great short entertainment.
Just don't expect anything too deep or meaningful.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Morningstar is a fairly decent point & click foundation but sadly it has one-dimentional characters and a nonexistent story built on top of it.

I can see why reviews here move the needle more towards the positive end of the spectrum, but what makes or breaks a P&C adventure for me isn't the puzzles or backgrounds, but the story and characters. These are the areas where Morningstar is most lacking. I didn't dislike this game as much as my thumbs down implies, but I did conclude it with a resounding, meh."

Pros:
-Pretty nice backgrounds and occasional animations
-Challenging
date:
yet rewarding puzzles
-Radio "hint" system that I was grateful for

Cons:
-Weak story. You crash on a planet
recommended: you work to get off of it. There's a mystery to the planet
hoursPlayed: but you won't get to the bottom of it\n-Incredibly corny and anticlimactic ending\n-Voice acting varies between "hammy" and "phoning it in""
